oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Certificate of enlistment for Dennis Morgan into the United States Colored Troops
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Morgan, William Henry, 1888-1939; Morgan, Dennis, 1838 - ; United States -- Army -- African American troops; African American soldiers -- Records and correspondence
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: One-sheet certificate of enlistment for Dennis Morgan, "a Colored man whom W. H. Morgan claims as his slave, April 5, 1864." Certificate includes Morgan's age and physical description, as well as the signature of L. E. Davis, First Sergeant, 17th regiment, United States Colored Troops. The certificate of muster on the lower half of document is blank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- War Dept. -- Adjutant General's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The U. S. War Dept. issued General Order No. 143 on May 22, 1863, establishing a "Bureau of Colored Troops." Around 175 United States Colored Troops regiments with over 178,000 soldiers (about 1/10 of all federal troops) served during the last two years of the Civil War. Black soldiers under the command of white officers received less pay than their white counterparts, were widely admired for their courage, and suffered high combat losses.
